chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:1
verses.text: Book II.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:2
verses.text: On the Belief in the Resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:3
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:4
verses.text: In the former book I indulged my longing to some extent, lest too sharp remedies applied to a burning wound might rather increase than assuage the pain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:5
verses.text: And as at the same time I often addressed my brother, and had him before my eyes, it was not out of place to let natural feelings have a little play, since they are somewhat satisfied by tears, soothed by weeping, and numbed by a shock.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:6
verses.text: For the outward expression of affection is of a soft and tender nature, it loves nothing extravagant, nothing stern, nothing hard; and patience is proved by enduring rather than by resisting.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:7
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:8
verses.text: So, since the death-day might well, lately, by the sad spectacle draw aside the mind of a brother, because it occupied him wholly, now, inasmuch as on the seventh day, the symbol of the future rest, we return to the grave, it is profitable to turn our thoughts somewhat from my brother to a general exhortation addressed to all, and to give our attention to this; so as neither to cling to my brother with all our minds, lest our feelings overcome us, nor forgetting such devotion and desert, to turn wholly away from him; and in truth we should but increase the suffering of our intense grief, if his death were again the subject of to-day's address.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:9
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:10
verses.text: Wherefore we propose, dearest brethren, to console ourselves with the common course of nature, and not to think anything hard which awaits all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:11
verses.text: And therefore we deem that death is not to be mourned over; firstly, because it is common and due to all; next, because it frees us from the miseries of this life and, lastly, because when in the likeness of sleep we are at rest from the toils of this world, a more lively vigour is shed upon us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:12
verses.text: What grief is there which the grace of the Resurrection does not console? What sorrow is not excluded by the belief that nothing perishes in death? nay, indeed, that by the hastening of death it comes to pass that much is preserved from perishing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:13
verses.text: So it will happen, dearest brethren, that in our general exhortation we shall turn our affections to my brother, and shall not seem to have wandered too far from him, if through hope of the Resurrection and the sweetness of future glory even in our discourse he should live again for us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:14
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:15
verses.text: Let us then begin at this point, that we show that the departure of our loved ones should not be mourned by us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:16
verses.text: For what is more absurd than to deplore as though it were a special misfortune, what one knows is appointed unto all? This were to lift up the mind above the condition of men, not to accept the common law, to reject the fellowship of nature, to be puffed up in a fleshly mind, and not to recognize the measure of the flesh itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:17
verses.text: What is more absurd than not to recognize what one is, to pretend to be what one is not? Or what can be a sign of less forethought than to be unable to bear, when it has happened, what one knew was going to happen? Nature herself calls us back, and draws us aside from sorrow of this sort by a kind of consolation of her own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:18
verses.text: For what so deep mourning is there, or so bitter grief, in which the mind is not at times relieved? For human nature has this peculiarity, that although men may be in sad circumstances, yet if only they be men, they sometimes turn their thoughts a little away from sadness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:19
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:20
verses.text: It is said, indeed, that there have been certain tribes who mourned at the birth of human beings, and kept festival at their deaths, and this not without reason, for they thought that those who had entered upon this ocean of life should be mourned over, but that they who had escaped from the waves and storms of this world should be accompanied by rejoicing not without good reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:21
verses.text: And we too forget the birthdays of the departed, and commemorate with festal solemnity the day on which they died.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:22
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:23
verses.text: Therefore, in accordance with nature, excessive grief must not be yielded to, lest we should seem either to claim for ourselves either an exceptional superiority of nature, or to reject the common lot.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:24
verses.text: For death is alike to all, without difference for the poor, without exception for the rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:25
verses.text: And so  although through the sin of one alone, yet it passed upon all; that we may not refuse to acknowledge Him to be also the Author of death, Whom we do not refuse to acknowledge as the Author of our race; and that, as through one death is ours, so should be also the resurrection; and that we should not refuse the misery, that we may attain to the gift.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:26
verses.text: For, as we read, Christ "is come to save that which was lost," and "to be Lord both of the dead and living".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:27
verses.text: In Adam I fell, in Adam I was cast out of Paradise, in Adam I died; how shall the Lord call me back, except He find me in Adam; guilty as I was in him, so now justified in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:28
verses.text: If, then, death be the debt of all, we must be able to endure the payment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:29
verses.text: But this topic must be reserved for later treatment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:30
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:31
verses.text: It is now our purpose to demonstrate that death ought not to cause too heavy grief, because nature itself rejects this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:32
verses.text: And so they say that there was a law among the Lycians, commanding that men who gave way to grief should be clothed in female apparel, inasmuch as they judged mourning to be soft and effeminate in a man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:33
verses.text: And it is inconsistent that those who ought to offer their breast to death for the faith, for religion, for their country, for righteous judgment, and the endeavour after virtue, should grieve too bitterly for that in the case of others which, if a fitting cause required, they would seek for themselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:34
verses.text: For how can one help shrinking from that in ourselves which one mourns with too little patience when it has happened to others? Put aside your grief, if you can; if you cannot, keep it to yourself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:35
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:36
verses.text: Is, then, all sorrow to be kept within or repressed? Why should not reason rather than time lighten one's sadness? Shall not wisdom better assuage that which the passage of time will obliterate? Further, it seems to me that it is a want of due feeling with regard to the memory of those whose loss we mourn, when we prefer to forget them rather than that our sorrow should be lessened by consolation; and to shrink from the recollection of them, rather than remember them with thankfulness; that we fear the calling to mind of those whose image in our hearts ought to be a delight; that we are rather distrustful than hopeful regarding the acceptance of the departed, and think of those we loved rather as liable to punishment than as heirs of immortality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:37
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:38
verses.text: But you may say: We have lost those whom we used to love.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:39
verses.text: Is not this the common lot of ourselves and the earth and elements, that we cannot keep for ever what has been entrusted to us for a time? The earth groans under the plough, is lashed by rains, struck by tempests, bound by cold, burnt by the sun, that it may bring forth its yearly fruits; and when it has clothed itself with a variety of flowers, it is stripped and spoiled of its own adornment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:40
verses.text: How many plunderers it has! And it does not complain of the loss of its fruits, to which it gave birth that it might lose them, nor thereafter does it refuse to produce what it remembers will be taken from it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:41
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:42
verses.text: The heavens themselves do not always shine with the globes of twinkling stars, wherewith as with coronets they are adorned.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:43
verses.text: They are not always growing bright with the dawn of light, or ruddy with the rays of the sun; but in constant succession that most pleasing appearance of the world grows dark with the damp chill of night.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:44
verses.text: What is more grateful than the light? what more pleasant than the sun? each of which daily comes to an end; yet we do not take it ill that these have passed away from us, because we expect them to return.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:45
verses.text: Thou art taught in these things what patience thou oughtest to manifest with regard to those who belong to thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:46
verses.text: If things above pass away from thee, and cause no grief, why should the passing away of man be mourned?  11.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:47
verses.text: Let, then, grief be patient, let there be that moderation in adversity which is required in prosperity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:48
verses.text: If it be not seemly to rejoice immoderately, is it seemly so to mourn? For want of moderation in grief or fear of death is no small evil.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:49
verses.text: How many has it driven to the halter, in how many hands has it placed the sword, that they might by that very means demonstrate their madness in not enduring death, and yet seeking it; in adopting that as a remedy which they flee from as an evil.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:50
verses.text: And because they were unable to endure and to suffer what is in agreement with their nature, they fall into that which is contrary to their desire, being separated for ever from those whom they desired to follow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:51
verses.text: But this is not common, since nature herself restrains although madness drives men on.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:52
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:53
verses.text: But it is common with women to make public wailing, as though they feared that their misery might not be known.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:54
verses.text: They affect soiled clothing, as though the feeling of sorrow consisted therein; they moisten their unkempt hair with filth; and  lastly, which is done habitually in many places, with their clothing torn and their dress rent in two, they prostitute their modesty in nakedness, as if they were ready to sacrifice that modesty because they have lost that which was its reward.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:55
verses.text: And so wanton eyes are excited, and lust after those naked limbs, which were they not made bare they would not desire.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:56
verses.text: Would that those filthy garments covered the mind rather than the bodily form.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:57
verses.text: Lasciviousness of mind is often hidden under sad clothing, and the unseemly rudeness of dress is used as a covering to hide the secrets of wanton spirits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:58
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:59
verses.text: She mourns for her husband with sufficient devotion who preserves her modesty and does not give up her constancy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:60
verses.text: The best duties to discharge to the departed are that they live in our memories and continue in our affection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:61
verses.text: She has not lost her husband who manifests her chastity, nor is she widowed as regards her union who has not changed her husband's name.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:62
verses.text: Nor hast thou lost the heir when thou assistest the joint-heir, but in exchange for a successor in perishable things thou hast a sharer in things eternal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:63
verses.text: Thou hast one to represent thine heir, pay to the poor what was due to the heir, that there may remain one to survive, not only the old age of father or mother, but thine own life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:64
verses.text: Thou leavest thy successor all the more, if his share conduce not to luxury in things present, but to the purchasing of things to come.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:65
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:66
verses.text: But we long for those whom we have lost.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:67
verses.text: For two things specially pain us: either the longing for those we have lost, which I experience in my own case; or that we think them deprived of the sweetness of life, and snatched away from the fruits of their toil.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:68
verses.text: For there is a tender movement of love, which suddenly kindles the affection, so as to have the effect rather of soothing than of hindering the pain; inasmuch as it seems a dutiful thing to long for what one has lost, and so under an appearance of virtue weakness increases.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:69
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:70
verses.text: But why dost thou think that she who has sent her beloved to foreign parts, and because of military service, or of undertaking some office, or has discovered that for the purpose of commerce he has crossed the sea, ought to be more patient than thou who art left, not because of some chance decision or desire of money, but by the law of nature? But, you say, the hope of regaining him is shut out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:71
verses.text: As though the return of any one were certain! And oftentimes doubt wearies the mind more where the fear of danger is strong; and it is more burdensome to fear lest something should happen than to bear what one already knows has happened.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:72
verses.text: For the one increases the amount of fear, the other looks forward to the end of its grief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:73
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:74
verses.text: But masters have the right to transfer their slaves whithersoever they determine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:75
verses.text: Has not God this right? It is not granted to us to look for their return, but it is granted us to follow those gone before.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:76
verses.text: And certainly the usual shortness of life seems neither to have deprived them of much who have gone before, nor to delay very long him who remains.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:77
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:78
verses.text: But if one cannot mitigate one's grief, does it not seem unbecoming to wish that because of our longing the whole course of things should be upset? The longings of lovers are certainly more intense, and yet they are tempered by regard to what is necessary; and though they grieve at being forsaken they are not wont to mourn, rather being deserted they blush at loving too hastily.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:79
verses.text: And so patience in regret is all the more manifested.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:80
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:81
verses.text: But what shall I say of those who think that the departed are deprived of the sweetness of life? There can be no real sweetness in the midst of the bitternesses and pains of this life, which are caused either by the infirmity of the body itself, or by the discomfort of things happening from without.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:82
verses.text: For we are always anxious and in suspense as to our wishes for happier circumstances; we waver in uncertainty, our hope setting before us doubtful things for certain, inconvenient for satisfactory, things that will fail for what is firm, and we have neither any strength in our will nor certainty in our wishes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:83
verses.text: But if anything happens against our wish, we think we are lost, and are rather broken down by pain at adversity than cheered by the enjoyment of prosperity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:84
verses.text: What good, then, are they deprived of who are rather freed from troubles?  19.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:85
verses.text: Good health, I doubt not, is more beneficial to us than bad health is hurtful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:86
verses.text: Riches bring more delights than poverty annoyance, the satisfaction in children's love is greater than the sorrow at their loss, and youth is more pleasant than old age is sad.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:87
verses.text: How often is the attainment of one's wishes a weariness, and what one has longed for a regret; so that one grieves at having obtained what one was not afraid of obtaining.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:88
verses.text: But what fatherland, what pleasures, can compensate for exile and the bitterness of other penalties? For even when we have  these, the pleasure is weakened either by the disinclination to use or by the fear of losing them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:89
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:90
verses.text: But suppose that some one remains unharmed, free from grief, in uninterrupted enjoyment of the pleasures of the whole course of man's life, what comfort can the soul attain to, enclosed in the bonds of a body of such a kind, and restrained by the narrow limits of the limbs? If our flesh shrinks from prison, if it abhors everything which denies it the power of roaming about; when it seems, indeed, to be always going forth, with its little powers of hearing or seeing what is beyond itself, how much more does our soul desire to escape from that prison-house of the body, which, being free with movement like the air, goes whither we know not, and comes whence we know not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:91
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:92
verses.text: We know, however, that it survives the body, and that being set free from the bars of the body, it sees with clear gaze those things which before, dwelling in the body, it could not see.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:93
verses.text: And we are able to judge of this by the instance of those who have visions of things absent and even heavenly in sleep (whose minds, when the body is as it were buried in sleep, rise to higher things and relate them to the body).

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:94
verses.text: So, then, if death frees us from the miseries of this world, it is certainly no evil, inasmuch as it restores liberty and excludes suffering.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:95
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:96
verses.text: At this point the right place occurs for arguing that death is not an evil, because it is the refuge from all miseries and all evils, a safe harbour of security, and a haven of rest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:97
verses.text: For what adversity is there which we do not experience in this life? What storms and tempests do we not suffer? by what discomforts are we not harassed? whose merits are spared?  23.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:98
verses.text: The holy patriarch Israel fled from his country, was exiled from his father, relatives, and home, he mourned over the shame of his daughter and the death of his son, he endured famine, when dead he lost his own grave, for he entreated that his bones should be translated, lest even in death he should find rest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:99
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:100
verses.text: Holy Joseph experienced the hatred of his brethren, the guile of those who envied him, the service of slavery, the mastership of merchantmen, the wantonness of his mistress, the ignorance of her husband, and the misery of prison.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:101
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:102
verses.text: Holy David lost two sons; the one incestuous, the other a parricide.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:103
verses.text: To have had them was a disgrace, to have lost them a grief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:104
verses.text: And he lost a third, the infant whom he loved.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:105
verses.text: Him he wept for while still alive, but did not long for when dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:106
verses.text: For so we read, that, while the child was sick, David entreated the Lord for him, and fasted and lay in sackcloth, and when the elders came near to raise him from the earth, he would neither rise nor eat.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:107
verses.text: But when he heard that the child was dead, he changed his clothes, worshipped God, and took food.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:108
verses.text: When this seemed strange to his servants, he answered that he had rightly fasted and wept while the child was alive, because he justly thought that God might have mercy, and it could not be doubted that He could preserve the life of one alive Who could give life to the departed, but now, when death had taken place, why should he fast, for he could not now bring back him that was dead, and recall him who was lifeless.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:109
verses.text: "I," said he, "shall go to him, but he shall not return to me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:110
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:111
verses.text: O greatest consolation for him who mourns! O true judgment of a wise man! O wonderful wisdom of one who is a bond-man! that none should take it ill that anything adverse has happened to him, or complain that he is afflicted contrary to his deserts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:112
verses.text: For who art thou who beforehand proclaimest thy deserts? Why desirest thou to anticipate Him Who takes cognizance of all? Why dost thou snatch away the verdict from Him Who is going to judge? This is permitted not even to the saints, nor has it ever been done by the saints with impunity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:113
verses.text: David confesses that he was scourged for this in his psalm: "Behold, these are the ungodly, who prosper in the world, they have obtained riches.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:114
verses.text: Therefore I have cleansed my heart in vain, and washed my hands among the innocent; and I was scourged all the day long, and my accusation came every morning".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:115
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:116
verses.text: Peter also, though full of faith and devotion, yet because, not yet conscious of our common weakness, he had presumptuously said to the Lord, "I will lay down my life for Thy sake," fell into the trial of his presumption before the cock crowed thrice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:117
verses.text: Although, indeed, that trial was a lesson for our salvation, that we might learn not to think little of the weakness of the  flesh, lest through thus thinking little of it we should be tempted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:118
verses.text: If Peter was tempted, who can presume? who can maintain that he cannot be tempted? And without doubt for our sakes was Peter tempted, so that, the proving of the temptation did not take place in a stronger than he, but that in him we should learn how, resisting in temptations, although tried even by care for our lives, we might yet overcome the sting of the temptation with tears of patience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:119
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:120
verses.text: But that same David, that the difference of his actions may not perhaps disturb those who cling to the words of Scripture; that same David, I say, who had not wept for the innocent infant, wept for the parricide when dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:121
verses.text: For at the last, when he was wailing and mourning, he said, "O my son Absalom, my son Absalom! Who will grant me to die for thee!" But not only is Absalom the parricide wept over, Amnon is wept over; not only is the incestuous wept over, but is even avenged; the one by the scorn of the kingdom, the other by the exile of his brothers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:122
verses.text: The wicked is wept over, not the innocent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:123
verses.text: What is the cause? What is the reason? There is no little deliberation with the prudent and confirmation of results with the wise; for there is great consistency of prudence in so great a difference of actions, but the belief is one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:124
verses.text: He wept for those who were dead, but did not think that he ought to weep for the dead infant, for he thought that they were lost to him, but hoped that the latter would rise again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:125
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:126
verses.text: But concerning the Resurrection more will be said later on; let us now return to our immediate subject.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:127
verses.text: We have set forth that even holy men have without any consideration for their merits, suffered many and heavy things in this world, together with toil and misery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:128
verses.text: So David, entering into himself, says: "Remember; Lord, that we are dust; as for man, his days are but as grass;" and in another place: "Man is like to vanity, his days pass away as a shadow".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:129
verses.text: For what is more wretched than we, who are sent into this life as it were plundered and naked, with frail bodies, deceitful hearts, weak minds, anxious in respect of cares, slothful as to labour, prone to pleasures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:130
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:131
verses.text: Not to be born is then by far the best, according to Solomon's sentence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:132
verses.text: For they also who have seemed to themselves to excel most in philosophy have followed him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:133
verses.text: For he, before these philosophers in time, but later than many of our writers, spoke thus in Ecclesiastes: "And I praised all the departed, which are already dead, more than the living, who are yet alive.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:134
verses.text: And better than both they is he who hath not yet been born, and who hath not seen this evil work which hath been done under the sun.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:135
verses.text: And I saw all travail, and all the good of this labour, that for this a man is envied of his neighbour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:136
verses.text: And, indeed, this is vanity and vexation of spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:137
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:138
verses.text: And who said this but he who asked for and obtained wisdom, to know how the world was made, and the power of the elements, the course of the year, and the dispositions of stars, to be acquainted with the natures of living creatures, the furies of wild beasts, and the violence of winds, and to understand the thoughts of man! How, then, should mortal matters be hidden from him, from whom heavenly things were not hidden? He who penetrated the thoughts of the woman who was claiming the child of another, who by the inspiration of divine grace knew the natures of living creatures which he did not share; could he err or say what was untrue with regard to the circumstances of that nature, which he found in his own personal experience?  32.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:139
verses.text: But Solomon was not the only person who felt this, though he alone gave expression to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:140
verses.text: He had read the words of holy Job: "Let the day perish wherein I was born".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:141
verses.text: Job had recognized that to be born is the beginning of all woes, and therefore wished that the day on which he was born might perish, so that the origin of all troubles might be removed, and wished that the day of his birth might perish that he might receive the day of resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:142
verses.text: For Solomon had heard his father's saying: "Lord, make me to know mine end, and the number of my days, that I may know what is lacking unto me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:143
verses.text: For David knew that what is perfect cannot be grasped here, and therefore hastened on to those things which are to come.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:144
verses.text: For now we know in part, and understand in part, but then it will be possible for that which is perfect to be grasped, when not the shadow but the reality of the Divine Majesty and eternity shall begin to shine so as to be gazed upon by us with unveiled face.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:145
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:146
verses.text: But no one would hasten to the end, except he were fleeing from the discomfort of this life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:147
verses.text: And so David also explained why he hastened to the end, when he said: "Behold Thou hast made my days old, and my being is as nothing before Thee, surely all things are vanity, even every man that liveth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:148
verses.text: Why, then, do we hesitate to flee from vanity? Or why does it please us to be troubled to no purpose in this world, to lay up treasures, and not know for what heir we are gathering them? Let us pray that troubles be removed from us, that we be taken out of this foolish world, that we may be free from our daily pilgrimage, and return to that country and our natural home.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:149
verses.text: For on this earth we are strangers and foreigners; we have to return thither whence we have come down, we must strive and pray not perfunctorily but earnestly to be delivered from the guile and wickedness of men full of words.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:150
verses.text: And he who knew the remedy groaned that his sojourn was prolonged, and that he must dwell with the unjust and sinners.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:151
verses.text: What shall I do, who both am sinful and know not the remedy?  34.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:152
verses.text: Jeremiah also bewails his birth in these words: "Woe is me, my mother! Why hast thou borne me a man of contention in all the earth? I have not benefited others, nor has any one benefited me, my strength hath failed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:153
verses.text: If, then, holy men shrink from life whose life, though profitable to us, is esteemed unprofitable to themselves; what ought we to do who am not able to profit others, and who feel that it, like money borrowed at interest, grows more heavily weighted every day with an increasing mass of sins?  35.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:154
verses.text: "I die daily," says the Apostle.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:155
verses.text: Better certainly is this saying than theirs who said that meditation on death was true philosophy, for they praised the study, he exercised the practice of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:156
verses.text: And they acted for themselves only, but Paul, himself perfect, died not for his own weakness but for ours.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:157
verses.text: But what is meditation on death but a kind of separation of body and soul, for death itself is defined as nothing else than the separation of body and soul? But this is in accordance with common opinion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:158
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:159
verses.text: But according to the Scriptures we have been taught that death is threefold.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:160
verses.text: One death is when we die to sin, but live to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:161
verses.text: Blessed, then, is that death which, escaping from sin, and devoted to God, separates us from what is mortal and consecrates us to Him Who is immortal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:162
verses.text: Another death is the departure from this life, as the patriarch Abraham died, and the patriarch David, and were buried with their fathers; when the soul is set free from the bonds of the body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:163
verses.text: The third death is that of which it is said: "Leave the dead to bury their own dead".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:164
verses.text: In that death not only the flesh but also the soul dies, for "the soul that sinneth, it shall die".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:165
verses.text: For it dies to the Lord, through the weakness not of nature but of guilt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:166
verses.text: But this death is not the discharge from this life, but a fall through error.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:167
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:168
verses.text: Spiritual death, then, is one thing, natural death another, a third the death of punishment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:169
verses.text: But that which is natural is not also penal, for the Lord did not inflict death as a penalty, but as a remedy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:170
verses.text: And to Adam when he sinned, one thing was appointed as a penalty, another for a remedy, when it was said: "Because thou hast hearkened unto the voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree of which I had commanded thee that of it alone thou shouldst not eat, cursed is the ground in thy labor; in sorrow shalt thou eat its fruit all the days of thy life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:171
verses.text: Thorns and thistles shall it bring forth to thee, and thou shalt eat the herb of the field.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:172
verses.text: In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat thy bread, till thou return to the earth from which thou wast taken".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:173
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:174
verses.text: Here you have the days of rest from penalties, for they contain the punishment decreed against the thorns of this life, the cares of the world, and the pleasures of riches which shut out the Word.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:175
verses.text: Death is given for a remedy, because it is the end of evils.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:176
verses.text: For God said not, "Because thou hast hearkened to the voice of the woman thou shalt return to the earth," for this would have been a penal sentence, as this one is, "The earth under curse shall bring forth thorns and thistles to thee;" but He said: "In sweat shalt thou eat thy bread until thou return to the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:177
verses.text: You see that death is rather the goal of our penalties, by which an end is put to the course of this life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:178
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:179
verses.text: So, then, death is not only not an evil, but is even a good thing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:180
verses.text: So that it is sought as a good, as it is written: "Men shall seek death and shall not find it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:181
verses.text: They will seek it who shall say to the mountains: "Fall on us, and to the hills, Cover us".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:182
verses.text: That soul, too, shall seek it which has sinned.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:183
verses.text: That rich man lying in hell shall seek it,  who wishes that his tongue should be cooled with the finger of Lazarus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:184
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:185
verses.text: We see, then, that this death is a gain and life a penalty, so that Paul says: "To me to live is Christ and to die is gain".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:186
verses.text: What is Christ but the death of the body, the breath of life? And so let us die with Him, that we may live with Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:187
verses.text: Let there then be in us as it were a daily practice and inclination to dying, that by this separation from bodily desires, of which we have spoken, our soul may learn to withdraw itself, and, as it were placed on high, when earthly lusts cannot approach and attach it to themselves, may take upon herself the likeness of death, that she incur not the penalty of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:188
verses.text: For the law of the flesh wars against the law of the mind, and makes it over to the law of error, as the Apostle has made known to us, saying: "For I see a law of the flesh in my members warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity in the law of sin".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:189
verses.text: We are all attached, we all feel this; but we are not all delivered.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:190
verses.text: And so a miserable man am I, unless I seek the remedy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:191
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:192
verses.text: But what remedy? "Who shall deliver me out of the body of this death? Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:193
verses.text: We have a physician, let us use the remedy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:194
verses.text: Our remedy is the grace of Christ, and the body of death is our body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:195
verses.text: Let us therefore be as strangers to our body, lest we be strangers to Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:196
verses.text: Though we are in the body, let us not follow the things which are of the body, let us not reject the rightful claims of nature, but desire before all the gifts of grace: "For to be dissolved and to be with Christ is far better; yet to abide in the flesh is more needful for your sakes".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:197
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:198
verses.text: But this need is not the case of all, Lord Jesus; it is not so with me, who am profitable to none; for to me death is a gain, that I may sin no more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:199
verses.text: To die is gain to me, who, in the very treatise in which I comfort others, am incited as it were by an intense impulse to the longing for my lost brother, since it suffers me not to forget him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:200
verses.text: Now I love him more, and long for him more intensely.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:201
verses.text: I long for him when I speak, I long for him when I read again what I have written, and I think that I am more impelled to write this, that I may not ever be without the recollection of him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:202
verses.text: And in this I am not acting contrary to Scripture, but I am of the same mind with Scripture, that I may grieve with more patience, and long with greater intensity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:203
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:204
verses.text: Thou hast caused me, my brother, not to fear death, and I only would that my life might die with thine! This Balaam wished for as the greatest good for himself, when, inspired by the spirit of prophecy, he said: "Let my soul die in the souls of the righteous, and let my seed be like the seed of them".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:205
verses.text: And in truth he wished this according to the spirit of prophecy, for as he saw the rising of Christ, so also he saw His triumph, he saw His death, but saw also in Him the everlasting resurrection of men, and therefore feared not to die as he was to rise again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:206
verses.text: Let not then my soul die in sin, nor admit sin into itself, but let it die in the soul of the righteous, that it may receive his righteousness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:207
verses.text: Then, too, he who dies in Christ is made a partaker of His grace in the Font.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:208
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:209
verses.text: Death is not, then, an object of dread, nor bitter to those in need, nor too bitter to the rich, nor unkind to the old, nor a mark of cowardice to the brave, nor everlasting to the faithful nor unexpected to the wise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:210
verses.text: For how many have consecrated their life by the renown of their death alone, how many have been ashamed to live, and have found death a gain! We have read how often by the death of one great nations have been delivered; the armies of the enemy have been put to flight by the death of the general, who had been unable to conquer them when alive.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:211
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:212
verses.text: By the death of martyrs religion has been defended, faith increased, the Church strengthened; the dead have conquered, the persecutors have been overcome.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:213
verses.text: And so we celebrate the death of those of whose lives we are ignorant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:214
verses.text: So, too, David rejoiced in prophecy at the departure of his own soul, saying: "Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:215
verses.text: He esteemed death better than life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:216
verses.text: The death itself of the martyrs is the prize of their life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:217
verses.text: And again, by the death of those at variance hatred is put an end to.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:218
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:219
verses.text: Why should more be said? By the death of One the world was redeemed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:220
verses.text: For Christ, had He willed, need not have died, but He neither thought that death should be shunned as though there were any cowardice in it, nor could He have saved us better than by dying.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:221
verses.text: And so His death is the life of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:222
verses.text: We are signed with the sign  of His death, we show forth His death when we pray; when we offer the Sacrifice we declare His death, for His death is victory, His death is our mystery, His death is the yearly recurring solemnity of the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:223
verses.text: What now should we say concerning His death, since we prove by this Divine Example that death alone found immortality, and that death itself redeemed itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:224
verses.text: Death, then, is not to be mourned over, for it is the cause of salvation for all; death is not to be shunned, for the Son of God did not think it unworthy of Him, and did not shun it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:225
verses.text: The order of nature is not to be loosed, for what is common to all cannot admit of exception in individuals.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:226
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:227
verses.text: And, indeed, death was no part of man's nature, but became natural; for God did not institute death at first, but gave it as a remedy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:228
verses.text: Let us then take heed that it do not seem to be the opposite.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:229
verses.text: For if death is a good, why is it written that "God made not death, but by the malice of men death entered into the world"? For of a truth death was no necessary part of the divine operation, since for those who were placed in paradise a continual succession of all good things streamed forth; but because of transgression the life of man, condemned to lengthened labour, began to be wretched with intolerable groaning; so that it was fitting that an end should be set to the evils, and that death should restore what life had lost.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:230
verses.text: For immortality, unless grace breathed upon it, would be rather a burden than an advantage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:231
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:232
verses.text: And if one consider accurately, it is not the death of our being, but of evil, for being continues, it is evil that perishes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:233
verses.text: That which has been rises again; would that as it is now free from sinning, so it were without former guilt! But this very thing is a proof that it is not the death of being, that we shall be the same persons as we were.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:234
verses.text: And so we shall either pay the penalty of our sins, or attain to the reward of our good deeds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:235
verses.text: For the same being will rise again, now more honourable for having paid the tax of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:236
verses.text: And then "the dead who are in Christ shall rise first; then, too, we who are alive," it is said, "shall together with them be caught up in the clouds into the air to meet the Lord, and so we shall always be with the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:237
verses.text: They first, but those that are alive second.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:238
verses.text: They with Jesus, those that are alive through Jesus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:239
verses.text: To them life will be sweeter after rest, and though the living will have a delightful gain, yet they will be without experience of the remedy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:240
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:241
verses.text: There is, then, nothing for us to fear in death, nothing for us to mourn, whether life which was received from nature be rendered up to her again, or whether it be sacrificed to some duty which claims it, and this will be either an act of religion or the exercise of some virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:242
verses.text: And no one ever wished to remain as at present.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:243
verses.text: This has been supposed to have been promised to John, but it is not the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:244
verses.text: We hold fast to the words, and deduce the meaning from them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:245
verses.text: He himself in his own writing denies that there was a promise that he should not die, that no one from that instance might yield to an empty hope.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:246
verses.text: But if to wish for this would be an extravagant hope, how much more extravagant were it to grieve without rule for what has happened according to rule!  50.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:247
verses.text: The heathen mostly console themselves with the thought, either of the common misery, or of the law of nature, or of the immortality of the soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:248
verses.text: And would that their utterances were consistent, and that they did not transmit the wretched soul into a number of ludicrous monstrosities and figures! But what ought we to do, whose reward is the resurrection, though many, not being able to deny the greatness of this gift, refuse to believe in it? And for this reason will we maintain it, not by one casual argument only, but by as many as we are able.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:249
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:250
verses.text: All things, indeed, are believed to be, either because of experience, or on grounds of reason, or from similar instances, or because it is fitting that they be, and each of these supports our belief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:251
verses.text: Experience teaches us that we are moved; reason, that which moves us must be considered the property of another power; similar instances show that the field has borne crops, and therefore we expect that it will continue to bear them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:252
verses.text: Fitness, because even where we do not think that there will be results, yet we believe that it is by no means fitting to give up the works of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:253
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:254
verses.text: Each, then, is supported by each.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:255
verses.text: But belief in the resurrection is inferred most clearly on three grounds, in which all are included.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:256
verses.text: These are reason, analogy from universal example, and the evidence of what has happened, since many have risen.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:257
verses.text: Reason is clear.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:258
verses.text: For since the whole course of our life consists in the union of body and soul, and the resurrection brings with it  either the reward of good works, or the punishment of wicked ones, it is necessary that the body, whose actions are weighed, rise again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:259
verses.text: For how shall the soul be summoned to judgment without the body, when account has to be rendered of the companionship of itself and the body?  53.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:260
verses.text: Rising again is the lot of all, but there is a difficulty in believing this, because it is not due to our deserts, but is the gift of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:261
verses.text: The first argument for the resurrection is the course of the world, and the condition of all things, the series of generations, the changes in the way of succession, the setting and rising of constellations, the ending of day and night, and their daily succession coming as it were again to life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:262
verses.text: And no other reason can exist for the fertile temperament of this earth, but that the divine order restores by the dews of night as much of that moisture from which all earthly things are produced, as the heat of the sun dries up by day.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:263
verses.text: Why should I speak of the fruits of the earth? Do they not seem to die when they fall, to rise again when they grow green once more? That which is sown rises again, that which is dead rises again, and they are formed once more into the same classes and kinds as before.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:264
verses.text: The earth first gave back these fruits, in these first our nature found the pattern of the resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:265
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:266
verses.text: Why doubt that body shall rise again from body? Grain is sown, grain comes up again: fruit is sown, fruit comes up again; but the grain is clothed with blossom and husk.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:267
verses.text: "And this mortal must put on immortality, and this corruptible must put on incorruption".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:268
verses.text: The blossom of the resurrection is immortality, the blossom of the resurrection is incorruption.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:269
verses.text: For what is more fruitful than perpetual rest? what supplied with richer store than everlasting security? Here is that abundant fruit, by whose increase man's nature shoots forth more abundantly after death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:270
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:271
verses.text: But you wonder how what has yielded to putrefaction can again become solid, how scattered particles can come together, those that are consumed be made good: you do not wonder how seeds broken up under the moist pressure of the earth grow green.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:272
verses.text: For certainly they too, rotting under contact with the earth, are broken up, and when the fertilising moisture of the soil gives life to the dead and hidden seeds, and, by the vital warmth, as it were breathes out a kind of soul of the green herb.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:273
verses.text: Then by little and little nature raises from the ground the tender stalk of the growing ear, and as a careful mother folds it in certain sheaths, lest the sharp ice should hurt it as it grows, and to protect it from too great heat of the sun; and lest after this the rain should break down the fruit itself escaping as it were from its first cradle and just grown up, or lest the wind should scatter it, or small birds destroy it, she usually hedges it around with a fence of bristling awn.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:274
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:275
verses.text: Why should one, then, be surprised if the earth give back those bodies of men which it has received, seeing that it gives life to, raises, clothes, protects, and defends whatsoever bodies of seeds it has received? Cease then to doubt that the trustworthy earth, which restores multiplied as it were by usury the seeds committed to it, will also restore the entrusted deposit of the race of man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:276
verses.text: And why should I speak of the kinds of trees, which spring up from seed sown, and with revivified fruitfulness bear again their opening fruits, and repeat the old shape and likeness, and certain trees being renewed continue through many generations, and in their endurance overpass the very centuries? We see the grape rot, and the vine come up again: a graft is inserted and the tree is born again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:277
verses.text: Is there this divine foresight for restoring trees, and no care for men? And He Who has not suffered to perish that which He gave for man's use, shall He suffer man to perish, whom he made after His own image?  57.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:278
verses.text: But it appears incredible to you that the dead rise again? "Thou foolish one, that which thou thyself sowest, does it not first die that it may be quickened?" Sow any dry seed you please, it is raised up.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:279
verses.text: But, you answer, it has the life-juice in itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:280
verses.text: And our body has its blood, has its own moisture.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:281
verses.text: This is the life-juice of our body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:282
verses.text: So that I think that the objection is exploded which some allege that a dry twig does not revive, and then endeavour to argue from this to the prejudice of the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:283
verses.text: For the flesh is not dry, since all flesh is of clay, clay comes from moisture—moisture from the earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:284
verses.text: Then, again, many growing plants, though always fresh, spring from dry and sandy soil, since the earth itself supplies sufficient moisture for itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:285
verses.text: Does the earth then, which continually restores all things, fail with regard to man? From what has been said it is clear that we must not doubt that it is rather in accordance with than contrary to nature; for it is natural that all  things living should rise again, but contrary to nature that they should perish.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:286
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:287
verses.text: We come now to a point which much troubles the heathen, how it can be that the earth should restore those whom the sea has swallowed up, wild beasts have torn to pieces or have devoured.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:288
verses.text: So, then, at last we necessarily come to the conclusion that the doubt is not as to belief in resurrection in general, but as to a part.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:289
verses.text: For, granted that the bodies of those torn in pieces do not rise again, the others do so, and the resurrection is not disproved, but a certain class is an exception.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:290
verses.text: Yet I wonder why they think there is any doubt even concerning these, as though not all things which are of the earth return to the earth, and crumble again into earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:291
verses.text: And the sea itself for the most part casts up on neighbouring shores whatever human bodies it has swallowed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:292
verses.text: And if this were not so, I suppose we are to believe that it would not be difficult for God to join together what was dispersed, to unite what was scattered; God, Whom the universe obeys, to Whom the dumb elements submit and nature serves; as though it were not a greater wonder to give life to clay than to join it together.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:293
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:294
verses.text: That bird in the country of Arabia, which is called the Phoenix, restored by the renovating juices of its flesh, after being dead comes to life again: shall we believe that men alone are not raised up again? Yet we know this by common report and the authority of writings, namely, that the bird referred to has a fixed period of life of five hundred years, and when by some warning of nature it knows that the end of its life is at hand, it furnishes for itself a casket of frankincense and myrrh and other perfumes, and its work and the time being together ended, it enters the casket and dies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:295
verses.text: Then from its juices a worm comes forth, and grows by degrees into the fashion of the same bird, and its former habits are restored, and borne up by the oarage of its wings it commences once more the course of its renewed life, and discharges a debt of gratitude.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:296
verses.text: For it conveys that casket, whether the tomb of its body or the cradle of its resurrection, in which quitting life it died, and dying it rose again, from Ethiopia to Lycaonia; and so by the resurrection of this bird the people of those regions understand that a period of five hundred years is accomplished.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:297
verses.text: So to that bird the five hundredth is the year of resurrection, but to us the thousandth: it has its resurrection in this world, we have ours at the end of the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:298
verses.text: Many think also that this bird kindles its own funeral pile, and comes to life again from its own ashes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:299
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:300
verses.text: But perhaps nature if more deeply investigated will seem to give a deeper reason for our belief: let our thoughts turn back to the origin and commencement of the creation of man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:301
verses.text: You are men and women, you are not ignorant of the things which have to do with human nature, and if any of you have not this knowledge, you know that we are born of nothing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:302
verses.text: But how small an origin for being so great as we are! And if I do not speak more plainly, yet you understand what I mean, or rather what I will not say.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:303
verses.text: Whence, then, is this head, and that wonderful countenance, whose maker we see not? We see the work, it is fashioned for various purposes and uses.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:304
verses.text: Whence is this upright figure, this lofty stature, this power of action, this quickness of perception, this capacity for walking upright? Doubtless the organs of nature are not known to us, but that which they effect is known.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:305
verses.text: Thou too wast once seed, and thy body is the seed of that which shall rise again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:306
verses.text: Listen to Paul and learn that thou art this seed: "It is sown in corruption, it shall rise in incorruption; it is sown in dishonour, it shall rise in glory; it is sown in weakness, it shall rise in power; it is sown a natural body, it shall rise a spiritual body".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:307
verses.text: Thou also, then, art sown as are other things, why wonderest thou if thou shalt rise again as shall others? But thou believest as to them, because thou seest; thou believest not this, because thou seest it not: "Blessed are they that have not seen, and yet have believed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:308
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:309
verses.text: However, before the season comes, those things also are not believed, for every season is not suited for the raising of seeds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:310
verses.text: Wheat is sown at one time, and comes up at another; at one time the vine is planted, at another the budding twigs begin to shoot, the foliage grows luxuriant, and the grape is formed; at one time the olive is planted, at another time, as though pregnant and loaded with its offspring of berries, it is bent down by the abundance of its fruit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:311
verses.text: But before its own period arrives for each, the produce is restricted, and that which bears has not the age of bearing in its own power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:312
verses.text: One may see the mother of all at one time disfigured with mould, at another bare of produce, at another green and full of flowers, at another dried up.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:313
verses.text: Any spot which might wish to be always clothed and never to lay aside the golden dress of its seeds, or the green dress of the meadows, would be barren in itself and unendowed with the gain of its own produce which it would have transferred to others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:314
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:315
verses.text: So, then, even if thou wilt not believe in our resurrection by faith nor by example, thou wilt believe by experience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:316
verses.text: For many products, as the vine, the olive, and different fruits, the end of the year is the fit time for ripening; and for us also the consummation of the world, as though the end of the year has set the fitting time for rising again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:317
verses.text: And fitly is the resurrection of the dead at the consummation of the world, lest after the resurrection we should have to fall back into this evil age.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:318
verses.text: For this cause Christ suffered that He might deliver us from this evil world; lest the temptations of this world should overthrow us again, and it should be an injury to us to come again to life, if we came to life again for sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:319
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:320
verses.text: So then we have both a reason and a time for the resurrection: a reason because nature in all its produce remains consistent with itself, and does not fail in the generation of men alone; a time because all things are produced at the end of the year.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:321
verses.text: For the seasons of the world consist of one year.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:322
verses.text: What wonder if the year be one since the day is one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:323
verses.text: For on one day the Lord hired the labourers to work in the vineyard, when He said, "Why stand ye here all the day idle?"  64.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:324
verses.text: The causes of the beginnings of all things are seeds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:325
verses.text: And the Apostle of the Gentiles has said that the human body is a seed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:326
verses.text: And so in succession after sowing there is the substance needful for the resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:327
verses.text: But even if there were no substance and no cause, who could think it difficult for God to create man anew whence He will and as He wills.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:328
verses.text: Who commanded the world to come into being out of no matter and no substance? Look at the heaven, behold the earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:329
verses.text: Whence are the fires of the stars? Whence the orb and rays of the sun? Whence the globe of the moon? Whence the mountain heights, the hard rocks, the woody groves? Whence are the air diffused around, and the waters, whether enclosed or poured abroad? But if God made all these things out of nothing (for "He spake and they were made, He commanded and they were created"), why should we wonder that which has been should be brought to life again, since we see produced that which had not been?  65.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:330
verses.text: It is a cause for wonder that though they do not believe in the resurrection, yet in their kindly care they make provision that the human race should not perish, and so say that souls pass and migrate into other bodies that the world may not pass away.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:331
verses.text: But let them say which is the most difficult, for souls to migrate, or to return; come back to that which is their own, or seek for fresh dwelling places.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:332
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:333
verses.text: But let those who have not been taught doubt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:334
verses.text: For us who have read the Law, the Prophets, the Apostles, and the Gospel it is not lawful to doubt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:335
verses.text: For who can doubt when he reads: "And in that time shall all thy people be saved which is written in the book; and many of them that sleep in the graves of the earth shall arise with one opening, these to everlasting life, and those to shame and everlasting confusion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:336
verses.text: And they that have understanding shall shine as the brightness of the firmament, and of the just many shall be as the stars for ever".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:337
verses.text: Well, then, did he speak of the rest of those that sleep, that one may understand that death lasts not for ever, which like sleep is undergone for a time, and is put off at its time; and he shows that the progress of that life which shall be after death is better than that which is passed in sorrow and pain before death, inasmuch as the former is compared to the stars, the latter is assigned to trouble.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:338
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:339
verses.text: And why should I bring together what is written elsewhere: "Thou shalt raise me up and I will praise Thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:340
verses.text: Or that other passage in which holy Job, after experiencing the miseries of this life, and overcoming all adversity by his virtuous patience, promised himself a recompense for present evils in the resurrection, saying: "Thou shalt raise up this body of mine which has suffered many evils".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:341
verses.text: Isaiah also, proclaiming the resurrection to the people, says that he is the announcer of the Lord's message, for we read thus: "For the mouth of the Lord hath spoken, and they shall say in that day".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:342
verses.text: And what the mouth  of the Lord declared that the people should say is set forth later on, where it is written: "Because of Thy fear, O Lord, we have been with child and have brought forth the Spirit of Thy Salvation, which Thou hast poured forth upon the earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:343
verses.text: They that inhabit the earth shall fall, they shall rise that are in the graves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:344
verses.text: For the dew which is from Thee is health for them but the land of the wicked shall perish.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:345
