verses.text: Go, O my people, and enter into thy chambers; hide thyself for a little until the Lord's wrath pass by".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:346
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:347
verses.text: How well did he by the chambers point out the tombs of the dead, in which for a brief space we are hidden, that we may be better able to pass to the judgment of God, which shall try us with the indignation due for our wickednesses.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:348
verses.text: He, then, is alive who is hidden and at rest, as though withdrawing himself from our midst and retiring, lest the misery of this world should entangle him with closer snares, for whom the heavenly oracles affirm by the voices of the prophets that the joy of the resurrection is reserved, and the soundness of their freed bodies procured by the divine deed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:349
verses.text: And dew is well used as a sign, since by it all vital seeds of the earth are raised to growth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:350
verses.text: What wonder is it, then, if the dust and ashes also of our failing body grow vigorous by the richness of the heavenly dew, and by the reception of this vital moistening the shapes of our limbs are refashioned and connected again with each other?  69.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:351
verses.text: And the holy prophet Ezekiel teaches and describes with a full exposition how vigour is restored to the dry bones, the senses return, motion is added, and the sinews coming back, the joints of the human body grow strong; how the bones which were very dry are clothed with restored flesh, and the course of the veins and the flow of the blood is covered by the veil of the skin drawn over them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:352
verses.text: As we read, the reviving multitude of human bodies seems to spring up under the very words of the prophet, and one can see on the widespread plain the new seed shoot forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:353
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:354
verses.text: But if the wise men of old believed that a crop of armed men sprang up in the district of Thebes from the sowing of the hydra's teeth, whereas it is certainly established that seeds of one kind cannot be changed into another kind of plant, nor bring forth produce differing from its own seeds, so that men should spring from serpents and flesh from teeth; how much more, indeed, is it to be believed that whatever has been sown rises again in its own nature, and that crops do not differ from their seed, that soft things do not spring from hard, nor hard from soft, nor is poison changed into blood; but that flesh is restored from flesh, bone from bone, blood from blood, the humours of the body from humours.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:355
verses.text: Can ye then, ye heathen, who are able to assert a change, deny a restoration of the nature? Can you refuse to believe the oracles of God, the Gospel, and the prophets, who believe empty fables?  71.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:356
verses.text: But let us now hear the prophet himself, who speaks thus: "The hand of the Lord was upon me, and the Lord led me forth in the Spirit, and placed me in the midst of the plain, and it was full of men's bones; and He led me through them round about, and, lo, there were very many bones on the face of the plain, and they were very dry.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:357
verses.text: And He said unto me: Son of man, can these bones live? And I said: Lord, Thou knowest; and He said to me: Prophesy over these bones, and thou shalt say unto them: O ye dry bones, hear the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:358
verses.text: Thus saith the Lord to these bones: Behold I bring upon you the Spirit of life, and I will lay sinews upon you, and will bring up flesh upon you, and will stretch skin over you, and will put My Spirit into you, and ye shall live, and know that I am the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:359
verses.text: And I prophesied as He commanded me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:360
verses.text: And it came to pass when I was prophesying all these things, lo, there was a great earthquake".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:361
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:362
verses.text: Note how the prophet shows that there was hearing and movement in the bones before the Spirit of life was poured upon them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:363
verses.text: For, above, both the dry bones are bidden to hear, as if they had the sense of hearing, and that upon this each of them came to its own joint is pointed out by the words of the prophet, for we read as follows: "And the bones came together, each one to its joint.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:364
verses.text: And I beheld, and, lo, sinews and flesh were forming upon them, and skin came upon them from above, and there was no Spirit in them".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:365
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:366
verses.text: Great is the lovingkindness of the Lord, that the prophet is taken as a witness of the future resurrection, that we, too might see it with his eyes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:367
verses.text: For all could not be taken as witnesses, but in that one all we are witnesses, for neither does lying come upon a holy man, nor error upon so great a prophet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:368
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:369
verses.text: Nor ought it to appear at all improbable, that at the command of God the bones were fitted again to their joints, since we have numberless instances in which nature has obeyed the commands of heaven; as the earth was bidden to bring forth the green herb, and did bring it forth; as the rock at the touch of the rod gave forth water for the thirsting people; and the hard stone poured forth streams by the mercy of God for those parched with heat.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:370
verses.text: What else did the rod changed into a serpent signify, than that at the will of God living things can be produced from those that are without life? Do you think it more incredible that bones should come together when bidden, than that streams should be turned back or the sea flee? For thus does the prophet testify: "The sea saw it and fled, Jordan was driven back".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:371
verses.text: Nor can there be any doubt about this fact, which was proved by the rescue of one and the destruction of the other of two peoples, that the waves of the sea stood restrained, and at the same time surrounded one people, and poured back upon the other for their death, that they might overwhelm the one, but preserve the other.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:372
verses.text: And what do we find in the Gospel itself? Did not the Lord Himself prove there that the sea grew calm at a word, the clouds were driven away, the blasts of the winds yielded, and that on the quieted shores the dumb elements obeyed God?  75.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:373
verses.text: But let us go on with the other points, that we may observe how by the Spirit of life the dead are quickened, they that lie in the graves arise, and the tombs are opened: "And He said unto me: Prophesy, son of man, and say to the Spirit, Come from the four winds of heaven, O Spirit, and breathe upon these dead, that they may live.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:374
verses.text: And I prophesied as He commanded me, and the Spirit of life entered into them, and they lived, and stood up on their feet, an exceeding great company.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:375
verses.text: And the Lord spake unto me, saying: Son of man, these bones are the whole house of Israel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:376
verses.text: For they say, Our bones are become dry, our hope is lost, we shall perish.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:377
verses.text: Therefore, prophesy and say: Thus saith the Lord: Behold I will open your graves, and will bring you up out of your graves into the land of Israel, and ye shall know that I am the Lord, when I shall open your graves, and bring forth My people out of the graves, and shall put My Spirit in you, and place you in your own land, and ye shall know that I am the Lord; I have spoken, and I will perform it, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:378
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:379
verses.text: We notice here how the operations of the Spirit of life are again resumed; we know after what manner the dead are raised from the opening tombs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:380
verses.text: And is it in truth a matter of wonder that the sepulchres of the dead are unclosed at the bidding of the Lord, when the whole earth from its utmost limits is shaken by one thunderclap, the sea overflows its bounds, and again checks the course of its waves? And finally, he who has believed that the dead shall rise again "in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump (for the trumpet shall sound)," "shall be caught up amongst the first in the clouds to meet Christ in the air;" he who has not believed shall be left, and subject himself to the sentence by his own unbelief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:381
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:382
verses.text: The Lord also shows us in the Gospel, to come now to instances, after what manner we shall rise again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:383
verses.text: "For He raised not Lazarus alone, but the faith of all; and if thou believest, as thou readest, thy spirit also, which was dead, revives with Lazarus".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:384
verses.text: For what does it mean, that the Lord went to the sepulchre and cried with a loud voice, "Lazarus, come forth," except that He would give us a visible proof, would set forth an example of the future resurrection? Why did He cry with a loud voice, as though He were not wont to work in the Spirit, to command in silence, but only that He might show that which is written: "In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump the dead shall rise again incorruptible"? For the raising of the voice answers to the peal of trumpets.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:385
verses.text: And He cried, "Lazarus, come forth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:386
verses.text: Why is the name added, except perchance lest one might seem to be raised instead of another, or that the resurrection were rather accidental than commanded.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:387
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:388
verses.text: So, then, the dead man heard, and came forth from the tomb, bound hand and foot with grave cloths, and his face was bound with a napkin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:389
verses.text: Conceive, if thou canst, how he makes his way with closed eyes, directs his steps with bound feet, and moves as though free with fastened limbs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:390
verses.text: The bands remained on him but did not restrain him, his eyes were covered yet they saw.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:391
verses.text: So, then, he saw who was rising again, who was walking, who was leaving  the sepulchre.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:392
verses.text: For when the power of the divine command was working, nature did not require its own functions, and brought, as it were, into extremity, obeyed no longer its own course, but the divine will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:393
verses.text: The bands of death were burst before those of the grave.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:394
verses.text: The power of moving was exercised before the means of moving were supplied.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:395
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:396
verses.text: If thou marvellest at this, consider Who gave the command, that thou mayest cease to wonder; Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:397
verses.text: the Power of God, the Life, the Light, the Resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:398
verses.text: The Power raised up him that was lying prostrate, the Life produced his steps, the Light drove away the darkness and restored his sight, the Resurrection renewed the gift of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:399
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:400
verses.text: Perchance it may trouble thee that the Jews took away the stone and loosened the grave cloths, and thou mayest haply be anxious as to who shall move the stone from thy tomb.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:401
verses.text: As though He Who could restore the Spirit could not remove the stone; or He Who made the bound to walk could not burst the bonds; or He Who had shed light upon the covered eyes could not uncover the face; or He Who could renew the course of nature could not cleave the stone! But, in order that they may believe their eyes who will not believe with their heart, they remove the stone, they see the corpse, they smell the stench, they loose the grave cloths.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:402
verses.text: They cannot deny that he is dead whom they behold rising again; they see the signs of death and the proofs of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:403
verses.text: What if, whilst they are busied, they are converted by the very toil itself? What if, while they hear, they believe their own ears? What if, while they behold, they are instructed by their own eyes? What if, while they loose the bonds, they free their own minds? What if, while Lazarus is being unbound, the people is set free, while they let Lazarus go, themselves return to the Lord? For, lastly, many who had come to Mary, seeing what had taken place, believed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:404
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:405
verses.text: And this was not the only instance which our Lord Jesus Christ set forth, but He raised others also, that we might at any rate believe more numerous instances.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:406
verses.text: He raised the young man again, moved by the tears of his widowed mother, when He came and touched the bier, and said: "Young man, I say unto thee, arise, and he that was dead sat up and began to speak".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:407
verses.text: As soon as he heard he forthwith sat up, he forthwith spake.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:408
verses.text: The working of power, then, is one thing, the order of nature is another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:409
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:410
verses.text: And what shall I say of the daughter of the ruler of the synagogue, at whose death multitudes were weeping and the flute-players piping? For the funeral solemnities were being performed because of the conviction of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:411
verses.text: How quickly at the word of the Lord does the spirit return, the reviving body rise up, and food is taken, that the evidence of life may be believed!  83.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:412
verses.text: And why should we wonder that the soul is restored at the word of God, that flesh returns to the bones, when we remember the dead raised by the touch of the prophet's body? Elijah prayed, and raised the dead child.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:413
verses.text: Peter in the name of Christ bade Tabitha rise and walk,and the poor rejoicing believed for the food's sake which she ministered to them, and shall we not believe for our salvation's sake? They purchased the resurrection of another by their tears, shall we not believe in the purchase of ours by the Passion of Christ? Who when He gave up the ghost, in order to show that He died for our resurrection, worked out the course of the resurrection; for so soon as "He cried again with a loud voice and gave up the ghost, the earth did quake, and the rocks were rent, and the tombs were opened, and many bodies of the saints which slept arose, and, going forth out of the tombs after His resurrection, came into the holy city and appeared unto many".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:414
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:415
verses.text: If these things happened when He gave up the ghost, why should we think them incredible when He shall return to judgment? especially since this earlier resurrection is a pledge of that future resurrection, and a pattern of that reality Which is to come; indeed, it is rather itself truth than a pattern.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:416
verses.text: Who, then, at the Lord's resurrection opened the graves, gave a hand to those who were rising, showed them the road to find the holy city? If there was no one, it was certainly the Divine Power which was working in the bodies of the dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:417
verses.text: Shall one seek for the aid of man where one sees the work of God?  85.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:418
verses.text: Divine action has no need of human assistance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:419
verses.text: God commanded that the heavens should come into existence, and it was done; He determined that the earth should be created, and it was created.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:420
verses.text: Who carried together the stones on his shoulders? who  supplied the expenses? who furnished assistance to God as He toiled? These things were made in a moment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:421
verses.text: Would you know how quickly? "He spake and they were made".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:422
verses.text: If the elements spring up at a word, why should the dead not rise at a word? For though they be dead, yet they once lived, once had the breath of life for feeling, and strength for acting; and there is a very great difference between not having been capable of life, and having remained lifeless.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:423
verses.text: The devil said: "Command this stone that it become bread".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:424
verses.text: He confesses that at the command of God nature can be transformed, dost thou not believe that at the command of God nature can be remade?  86.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:425
verses.text: Philosophers dispute about the course of the sun and the system of the heavens, and there are those who think that these should be believed when they are ignorant of what they are talking about.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:426
verses.text: For neither have they climbed up into the heavens, nor measured the sky, nor examined the universe with their eyes; for none of them was with God in the beginning, none of them has said of God: "When He was preparing the heavens I was with Him, I was with Him as a master workman, I was he in whom He delighted".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:427
verses.text: If, then, they are believed, is God not believed, Who says: "As the new heavens and the new earth, which I make to remain before Me, saith the Lord; so shall your name and your seed abide; and month shall be after month, and sabbath after sabbath, and all flesh shall come in My sight to worship in Jerusalem, saith the Lord God; and they shall go forth, and shall see the limbs of men who have transgressed against Me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:428
verses.text: For their worm shall not die and their fire shall not be quenched and they shall be a sight to all flesh".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:429
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:430
verses.text: If the earth and heaven are renewed, why should we doubt that man, on account of whom heaven and earth were made, can be renewed? If the transgressor be reserved for punishment, why should not the just be kept for glory? If the worm of sins does not die, how shall the flesh of the just perish? For the resurrection, as the very form of the word shows, is this, that what has fallen should rise again, that which has died should come to life again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:431
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:432
verses.text: And this is the course and ground of justice, that since the action of body and soul is common to both (for what the soul has conceived the body has carried out), each should come into judgment, and each should be either given over to punishment or reserved for glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:433
verses.text: For it would seem almost inconsistent that, since the law of the mind fights against the law of the flesh, and the mind often, when sin dwelling in man acts, does that which it hates; the mind guilty of a fault shared by another should be subjected to penalty, and the flesh, the author of the evil, should enjoy rest: and that should alone suffer which had not sinned alone, or should alone attain to glory, not having fought alone with the help of grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:434
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:435
verses.text: The reason, unless I am mistaken, is complete and just, but I do not require a reason from Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:436
verses.text: If I am convinced by reason I reject faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:437
verses.text: Abraham believed God, let us also believe Him, that we who are heirs of his race may also be heirs of his faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:438
verses.text: David likewise believed, and therefore did he speak; let us also believe that we may be able to speak, knowing that "He Who raised up the Lord Jesus shall raise up us also with Jesus".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:439
verses.text: For God, Who never lies, promised this; the Truth promised this in His Gospel, when He said: "This is the will of Him that sent Me, that of all that which He hath given Me I should lose nothing, but should raise it up at the last day".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:440
verses.text: And He thought it not sufficient to have said this once, but marked it by express repetition, for this follows: "For this is the will of My Father, Who sent Me, that every one that seeth the Son and believeth on Him should have eternal life, and I will raise him up at the last day".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:441
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:442
verses.text: Who was He that said this? He in truth Who when dead raised up many bodies of the departed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:443
verses.text: If we believe not God, shall we not believe evidence? Do we not believe what He promised, since He did even that which He did not promise? And what reason would He have had for dying, had He not also had a reason for rising again? For, seeing that God could not die, Wisdom could not die; and inasmuch as that could not rise again which had not died, flesh is assumed, which can die, that whilst that, whose nature it is, dies, that which had died should rise again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:444
verses.text: For the resurrection could not be effected except by man; since, "as by man came death, so too by man came the resurrection of the dead".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:445
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:446
verses.text: So, then, man rose because man died; man was raised again, but God raised him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:447
verses.text: Then it was man according to the Flesh, now God is all in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:448
verses.text: For now we know not Christ according to the flesh, but we possess the grace of that Flesh, so that we know Him the firstfruits of them that rest, the firstborn of the dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:449
verses.text: Now the first-fruits are undoubtedly of the same nature and kind as the remaining fruits, the first of which are offered to God as a petition for a richer increase, as a holy thank-offering for all gifts, and as a kind of libation of that nature which has been restored.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:450
verses.text: Christ, then, is the firstfruits of them that rest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:451
verses.text: But is this of His own who are at rest, who, as it were, freed from death, are holden by a kind of sweet slumber, or of all those who are dead? "As in Christ all die, so too in Christ shall all be made alive".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:452
verses.text: So, then, as the firstfruits of death were in Adam, so also the firstfruits of the resurrection are in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:453
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:454
verses.text: All men rise again, but let no one lose heart, and let not the just grieve at the common lot of rising again, since he awaits the chief fruit of his virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:455
verses.text: All indeed shall rise again, but, as says the Apostle, "each in his own order".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:456
verses.text: The fruit of the Divine Mercy is common to all, but the order of merit differs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:457
verses.text: The day gives light to all, the sun warms all, the rain fertilises the possessions of all with genial showers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:458
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:459
verses.text: We are all born, and we shall all rise again, but in each state, whether of living or of living again, grace differs and the condition differs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:460
verses.text: For, "in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump, the dead shall rise incorruptible and we shall be changed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:461
verses.text: Moreover, in death itself some rest, and some live.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:462
verses.text: Rest is good, but life is better.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:463
verses.text: And so the Apostle rouses him that is resting to life, saying: "Rise, thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:464
verses.text: Therefore he is aroused that he may live, that he may be like to Paul, that he may be able to say: "For we that are alive shall not prevent those that are asleep".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:465
verses.text: He speaks not here of the common manner of life, and the breath which we all alike enjoy, but of the merit of the resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:466
verses.text: For, having said, "And the dead which are in Christ shall rise first," he adds further; "And we that are alive shall together with them be caught up in the clouds, to meet Christ in the air".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:467
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:468
verses.text: Paul certainly is dead, and by his honourable passion exchanged the life of the body for everlasting glory; did he then deceive himself when he wrote that he should be caught up alive in the clouds to meet Christ? We read the same too of Enoch and of Elijah, and thou too shalt be caught up in the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:469
verses.text: Lo the chariot of Elijah, lo the fire, though not seen are prepared, that the just may ascend, the innocent be borne forth, and thy life may not know death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:470
verses.text: For indeed the apostles knew not death, according to that which was said: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, many of those standing here shall not taste death until they see the Son of man coming in His kingdom".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:471
verses.text: For he lives, who has nothing in him which can die, who has not from Egypt any shoe or bond, but has put it off before laying aside the service of this body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:472
verses.text: And so not Enoch alone is alive, for not he alone was caught up; Paul also was caught up to meet Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:473
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:474
verses.text: The patriarchs also live, for God could not be called the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, except the dead were living; for He is not the God of the dead but of the living.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:475
verses.text: And we, too, shall live if we be willing to copy the deeds and habits of our predecessors.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:476
verses.text: We are astonished at the rewards of the patriarchs, let us copy their faithfulness; we tell of their grace, let us follow their obedience; let us not, enticed by appetite, fall into the snares of the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:477
verses.text: Let us lay hold of the opportunity, of the commandment of the Law, the mercy of our vocation, the desire of suffering.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:478
verses.text: The patriarchs went forth from their own land, let us go forth in purpose from the power of the body; let us go forth in purpose as they in exile; but they esteemed that not to be exile which the fear of God caused, necessity did not enforce.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:479
verses.text: They changed their land for another soil, let us change earth for heaven; they changed in earthly habitation, let us change in spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:480
verses.text: To them Wisdom showed the heaven illuminated with stars, let it enlighten the eyes of our heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:481
verses.text: Thus does the type agree with the truth, and the truth with the type.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:482
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:483
verses.text: Abraham, ready to receive strangers, faithful towards God, devoted in ministering, quick in his service, saw the Trinity in a type; he added religious duty to hospitality, when beholding Three he worshipped One, and preserving the distinction of the Persons, yet addressed one Lord, he offered to Three the honour of his gift, while  acknowledging one Power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:484
verses.text: It was not learning but grace which spoke in him, and he believed better what he had not learnt than we who have learnt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:485
verses.text: No one had falsified the representation of the truth, and so he sees Three, but worships the Unity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:486
verses.text: He brings forth three measures of fine meal, and slays one victim, considering that one sacrifice is sufficient, but a triple gift; one victim, an offering of three.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:487
verses.text: And in the four kings, who does not understand that he subjected to himself the elements of the material creation, and all earthly things in a sign whereby the Lord's Passion was prefigured? Faithful in war, moderate in his triumph, in that he preferred not to become richer by the gifts of men, but by those of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:488
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:489
verses.text: He believed that he when old could beget a son, and judged himself when a father able to sacrifice his son; nor did his fatherly affection tremble when duty aided the right hand of the old man, for he knew that his son would be more acceptable to God when sacrificed than when whole.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:490
verses.text: Therefore he brings his well-beloved son to be sacrificed, and offered promptly him whom he had received late; nor is he restrained by being called by the name of father, when his son called him "Father," and he replied, "My son".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:491
verses.text: Dear pledges of love are these names, but the commands of God are loved still more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:492
verses.text: And so although their hearts felt for each other, their purpose remained firm.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:493
verses.text: The father's hand stretched out the knife over his son, and the father's heart struck the blow that the sentence might not fail of being carried out; he feared lest the stroke should miss, lest his right hand should fail.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:494
verses.text: He felt the movings of fatherly affection, but did not shrink from the work of submission, and hastened his obedience, even when he heard the voice from heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:495
verses.text: Let us then set God before all those whom we love, father, brother, mother, that He may preserve for us those whom we love, as in the case of Abraham we behold rather the liberal Rewarder than the servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:496
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:497
verses.text: The father offered indeed his son, but God is appeased not by blood but by dutiful obedience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:498
verses.text: He showed the ram in the thicket in the stead of the lad, that He might restore the son to his father, and yet the victim not fail the priest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:499
verses.text: And so Abraham was not stained with his son's blood, nor was God deprived of the sacrifice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:500
verses.text: The prophet spoke, and neither yielded to boastfulness nor continued obstinate, but took the ram in exchange for the lad.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:501
verses.text: And by this is shown the more how piously he offered him whom he now so gladly received back.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:502
verses.text: And thou, if thou offer thy gift to God, dost not lose it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:503
verses.text: But we are tenacious of our own; God gave His only Son for us, we refuse ours.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:504
verses.text: Abraham saw this and recognized the mystery, that salvation should be to us from the Tree, nor did it escape his notice that in one and the same sacrifice it was One that seemed to be offered, Another which could be slain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:505
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:506
verses.text: Let us, then, imitate the devotion of Abraham, let us imitate the goodness of Isaac, let us imitate his purity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:507
verses.text: The man was plainly good and chaste, full of devotion towards God, chaste towards his wife.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:508
verses.text: He returned not evil for evil, yielded to those who would thrust him out, received them again on their repentance, neither violent towards insolence, nor stubborn towards kindness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:509
verses.text: Fleeing from strife when he went away from others, ready to forgive when he received them again, and still more lavish of goodness when he forgave them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:510
verses.text: The fellowship of his company was sought, he gave in addition a feast of pleasure.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:511
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:512
verses.text: In Jacob, too, let us imitate the type of Christ, let there be some likeness of his actions in ourselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:513
verses.text: We shall have our share with him, if we imitate him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:514
verses.text: He was obedient to his mother, he yielded to his brother, he served his father-in-law, he sought his wages from the increase, not from a division of the flocks.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:515
verses.text: There was no covetous division, where his portion brought such gain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:516
verses.text: Nor was that sign without a purpose, the ladder from earth to heaven, wherein was seen the future fellowship between men and angels through the cross of Christ, whose thigh was paralyzed, that in his thigh he might recognize the Heir of his body, and foretell by the paralyzing of his thigh the Passion of his Heir.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:517
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:518
verses.text: We see, then, that heaven is open to virtue, and that this is the privilege not only of a few: "For many shall come from the east and from the west, and the north and the south, and shall sit down in the kingdom of God," giving expression to the enjoyment of perpetual rest since the motions of their souls are stilled.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:519
verses.text: Let us follow Abraham in our habits, that he may receive us into his bosom, and cherish us with loving embrace, like Lazarus the inheritor of his humility surrounded by his own special virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:520
verses.text: The followers of the holy patriarch, approved of God, cherish us not in a bodily bosom, but in a clothing as it were of good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:521
verses.text: "Be not deceived," says the Apostle, "God is not mocked".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:522
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:523
verses.text: We have seen, then, how grave an offence it is not to believe the resurrection; for if we rise not again, then Christ died in vain, then Christ rose not again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:524
verses.text: For if He rose not for us, He certainly rose not at all, for He had no need to rise for Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:525
verses.text: The universe rose again in Him, the heaven rose again in Him, the earth rose again in Him, for there shall be a new heaven and a new earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:526
verses.text: But where was the necessity of a resurrection for Him Whom the claims of death held not? For though He died as man, yet was He free in hell itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:527
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:528
verses.text: Wilt thou know how free? "I am become as a man that hath no help, free among the dead".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:529
verses.text: And well is He called free, Who had power to raise Himself, according to that which is written: "Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:530
verses.text: And well is He called free, Who had descended to rescue others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:531
verses.text: For He was made as a man, not, indeed, in appearance only, but so fashioned in truth, for He is man, and who shall know Him? For, "being made in the likeness of men, and being found in fashion as a man, He humbled Himself, becoming obedient even unto death," in order that through that obedience we might see His glory, "the glory as of the Only-begotten of the Father," according to Saint John.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:532
verses.text: For thus is the statement of Scripture preserved, if both the glory of the Only-begotten and the nature of perfect man are preserved in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:533
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:534
verses.text: And so He needed no helper.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:535
verses.text: For He needed none when He made the world, so as to need none when He would redeem it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:536
verses.text: No legate, no messenger, but the Lord Himself made it whole.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:537
verses.text: "He spake and it was done".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:538
verses.text: The Lord Himself made it whole, Himself in every part, because all things were by Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:539
verses.text: For who should help Him in Whom all things were created and by Whom all things consist? Who should help Him Who makes all things in a moment, and raises the dead at the last trump? The "last," not as though He could not raise them at the first, or the second, or the third, but an order is observed, not that a difficulty may be at last overcome, but that the prescribed number be accomplished.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:540
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:541
verses.text: But it is now time, I think, to speak of the trumpets since my discourse is nearing its end, that the trumpet may also be the sign of the finishing of my address.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:542
verses.text: We read of seven trumpets in the Revelation of John, which seven angels received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:543
verses.text: And there you read that when the seventh angel sounded his trumpet, there was a great voice from heaven, saying: "The kingdom of this world is become the kingdom of our God and of His Christ, and He shall reign for ever and ever".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:544
verses.text: The word trumpet is also used for a voice, as you read: "Behold a door opened in heaven, and the first voice which I heard, as of a trumpet speaking with me and saying, Come up hither, and I will show thee the things which must come to pass".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:545
verses.text: We read also: "Blow up the trumpet at the beginning of the month [the new moon]"; and again elsewhere: "Praise Him with the sound of the trumpet".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:546
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:547
verses.text: Therefore we ought with all our power to observe what is the signification of the trumpets, lest, accepting them, like old women, as part of the story, we should be in danger if we were to think things unworthy of spiritual teaching, or not befitting the dignity of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:548
verses.text: For when we read that our warfare is not against flesh and blood, but against spiritual hosts of wickedness, which are in high places, we ought not to think of weapons of the flesh, but of such as are mighty before God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:549
verses.text: It is not enough that one see the trumpet or hear its sound, unless one understands the signification of the sound.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:550
verses.text: For if the trumpet give an uncertain sound, how shall one prepare himself for war? Wherefore it is important that we understand the meaning of the voice of the trumpet, lest we seem barbarians, when we either hear or utter trumpet-sounds of this sort.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:551
verses.text: And therefore when we speak, let us pray that the Holy Spirit would interpret them to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:552
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:553
verses.text: Let us, then, investigate what we read in the Old Testament concerning the kinds of trumpets, considering that those festivals which were enjoined on the Jews by the Law are the shadow of joys above and of heavenly festivals.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:554
verses.text: For here is the shadow, there the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:555
verses.text: Let us endeavour to attain to the truth by means of the shadow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:556
verses.text: Of which truth the figure is expressed in this manner, where we read that the Lord said  to Moses: "Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, In the seventh month, on the first day of the month, shall be a rest unto you, a memorial of blowing of trumpets, it shall be called holy unto you.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:557
verses.text: Ye shall not do any servile work, and ye shall kindle a whole burnt-offering unto the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:558
verses.text: And in the Book of Numbers: "The Lord spake unto Moses, saying: Make thee two trumpets of beaten work, of silver shalt thou make them, and they shall be to thee for calling the assembly and for the journeying of the camp.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:559
verses.text: And thou shalt blow with them, and all the congregation shall be gathered together at the door of the tabernacle of witness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:560
verses.text: But if thou blow with one trumpet, all the princes and leaders of Israel shall come to thee; and ye shall blow a signal with the trumpet the first time, and they shall move the camp forward, and place it on the east.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:561
verses.text: And ye shall blow a signal with the trumpet the second time, and they shall move the camp forward, and place it towards Libanus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:562
verses.text: And ye shall blow a signal with the trumpet the third time, and they shall move the camp forward, which shall be placed towards the north [Boream].

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:563
verses.text: And ye shall blow a signal with the trumpet the fourth time, and they shall move the camp forward, which shall be placed towards the north [Aquilonem].

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:564
verses.text: They shall blow a signal with the trumpet when they move forward.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:565
verses.text: And when ye shall gather together the assembly, blow with the trumpet, but not the signal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:566
verses.text: And the sons of Aaron, the priests, shall blow with the trumpets, and it shall be for you a statute for ever throughout your generations.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:567
verses.text: But if ye shall go out to war into your own land, against the adversaries who resist you, ye shall sound a signal with the trumpets and ye shall be remembered before the Lord, and have deliverance from your dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:568
verses.text: Also in the days of your gladness, and on your feast days, and on your new moons, ye shall blow with the trumpets, and at your whole burnt sacrifices and at your peace-offerings, and it shall be for you for your memorial before the Lord, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:569
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:570
verses.text: What then? shall we esteem festival days by eating and drinking? But let no man judge us in respect of eating; "for we know that the Law is spiritual".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:571
verses.text: "Let no man therefore judge us in any meats or in drink, or in respect of a feast day or new moons, or a sabbath day, which are a shadow of the things to come, but the body is of Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:572
verses.text: Let us, then, seek the body of Christ which the voice of the Father, from heaven, as it were the last trumpet, has shown to you at the time when the Jews said that it thundered; the body of Christ, which again the last trump shall reveal; for "the Lord Himself shall descend from heaven at the voice of the Archangel, and at the trump of God, and they that are dead in Christ shall rise again;" for "where the body is, there too are the eagles," where the body of Christ is, there is the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:573
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:574
verses.text: The seventh trumpet, then, seems to signify the sabbath of the week, which is reckoned not only in days and years and periods (for which reason the number of the jubilee is sacred), but includes also the seventieth year, when the people returned to Jerusalem, who had remained seventy years in captivity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:575
verses.text: In hundreds also and in thousands the observation of the sacred number is by no means passed over, for not without a meaning did the Lord say: "I have left the seven thousand men, who have not bent their knees before Baal".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:576
verses.text: Therefore the shadow of the future rest is figured in time in the days, months, and years of this world, and therefore the children of Israel are commanded by Moses, that in the seventh month, on the first day of the month, a rest should be established for all at the "memorial of the trumpets;" and that no servile work should be done, but a sacrifice be offered to God, because that at the end of the week, as it were the sabbath of the world, spiritual and not bodily work is required of us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:577
verses.text: For that which is bodily is servile, for the body serves the soul, but innocence makes free, guilt reduces to slavery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:578
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:579
verses.text: It was necessary, then, that spiritual things should be made known as in a mirror and in a riddle; "For now we see by means of a mirror, but then face to face".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:580
verses.text: Now we war after the flesh, then in the Spirit we shall see the divine mysteries.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:581
verses.text: Let, then, the character of the true law be expressed in our manner of life, who walk in the image of God, for the shadow of the Law has now passed away.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:582
verses.text: The carnal Jews had the shadow, the likeness is ours, the reality theirs who shall rise again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:583
verses.text: For we  know that according to the Law there are these three, the shadow, the image or likeness, and the reality; the shadow in the Law, the image in the Gospel, the truth in the judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:584
verses.text: But all is Christ's, and all is in Christ, Whom now we cannot see according to the reality, but we see Him, as it were, in a kind of likeness of future things, of which we have seen the shadow in the Law.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:585
verses.text: So, then, Christ is not the shadow but the likeness of God, not an empty likeness but the reality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:586
verses.text: And so the Law was by Moses, for the shadow was through man, the likeness was through the Law, the reality through Jesus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:587
verses.text: For reality cannot proceed from any other source than from reality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:588
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:589
verses.text: If, then, any one desires to see this Image of God, he must love God, that he may be loved by God; and be no longer a servant but a friend, because he has kept the commandments of God, that he may enter into the cloud where God is.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:590
verses.text: Let him make to himself two reasonable trumpets of beaten work of proved silver, that is, composed of precious words and adorned, from which not a harsh shrill sound with dread-inspiring voice may be uttered, but high thanks to God may be poured forth with continuous exultation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:591
verses.text: For by the voice of such trumpets the dead are raised, not indeed by the sound of the metal, but aroused by the word of truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:592
verses.text: And perchance it is those two trumpets by which Paul, through the Divine Spirit, spake when he said: "I will pray with the Spirit, and I will pray with the understanding, I will sing with the Spirit, and I will sing with the understanding;" for the one without the other seems by no means to have perfect utterance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:593
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:594
verses.text: Yet it is not every one's business to sound each trumpet, nor every one's business to call together the whole assembly, but that prerogative is granted to the priests alone, and the ministers of God who sound the trumpets, so that whosoever shall hear and follow thither where the glory of the Lord is, and shall with early determination come to the tabernacle of witness, may be able also to see the divine works, and merit that appointed and eternal home for the entire succession of his posterity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:595
verses.text: For then is the war finished and the enemy put to flight, when the grace of the Spirit and the energy of the soul act together.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:596
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:597
verses.text: And these are salutary trumpets also, if one believe with the heart, and confess with the mouth; "For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness, and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:598
verses.text: For with this twofold trumpet man arrives at that holy land, namely, the grace of the resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:599
verses.text: Let them, then, ever sound to thee, that thou mayest ever hear the voice of God; may the utterances of the Angels and Prophets ever incite and move thee, that thou mayest hasten to things above.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:600
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:601
verses.text: David was thinking of this purpose in his breast when he said: "For I will pass into the place of the marvellous tabernacle, even to the house of God, with the voice of exultation and thanksgiving, the sound of one that feasts".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:602
verses.text: For not only are enemies overcome by the sound of these trumpets; but without them there could not be rejoicings, and festivals or new moons.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:603
verses.text: For no one, unless he have received the promises of the Divine Word, and believes the message derived therefrom, can keep festivals or new moons, in which he desires to fill himself, freed from bodily pleasure and secular occupation, with the light of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:604
verses.text: And sacrifices themselves cannot be pleasing to Christ unless confession of the mouth accompanies them, which according to custom stirs up the people to implore the grace of God at the priestly oblation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:605
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:606
verses.text: Let us therefore be preachers of the Lord, and praise Him in the sound of the trumpet, not thinking little or lightly of its power, but such things as can fill the ear of the mind, and enter into the depths of our inmost consciousness, so that we think not that what suits to the body is to be applied to the Godhead, nor measure the greatness of Divine Power by human might, so as to enquire how any one can rise again, or with what kind of body he will come, or how that which has been dissolved can again coalesce, and what is lost be restored, for all these things are accomplished as soon as they are determined by the Divine Will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:607
verses.text: And it is not a sound of a trumpet distinguishable by the bodily senses which is expected, but the invisible power of the Majesty of heaven operates; for with God to will is to do; nor need we enquire into the force required for the resurrection, but seek its fruit for ourselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:608
verses.text: Which will be accomplished all the more easily, if freed from faults we attain to the fulness of the spiritual mystery, and the renewed flesh receives grace from the Spirit, and the soul  obtains from Christ the brightness of eternal light.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:609
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:610
verses.text: But those mysteries pertain not to individuals only, but to the whole human race.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:611
verses.text: For observe the order of grace according to the type of the Law.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:612
verses.text: When the first trumpet sounds, it collects those towards the east, as the chief and elect; when the second sounds, those nearly equal in merit, who, being placed towards Libanus, have abandoned the follies of the nations; when the third, those who as it were, tossed on the sea of this world, have been driven hither and thither by the waves of this life; when the fourth, those who have by no means been able sufficiently to soften the hardness of their hearts by the commandments of spiritual utterance, and therefore are said to be towards the north—for, according to Solomon, the north is a hard wind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:613
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:614
verses.text: And so although all are raised again in a moment, yet all are raised in the order of their merits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:615
verses.text: And therefore they rise first, who yielding early to the impulses of devotion, and as it were going forth before the rising dawn of faith, received the rays of the eternal Sun.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:616
verses.text: This one may rightly say either of the patriarchs in the course of the Old Testament, or of the apostles under the Gospel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:617
verses.text: And the second are they who, forsaking the rites of the Gentiles, passed from unholy error under the training of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:618
verses.text: So, then, those first were of the fathers, those second of the Gentiles, for the light of faith took its beginning from those, among these it will remain to the end of the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:619
verses.text: In the third place and in the fourth, those are raised who are in the south and in the north.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:620
verses.text: The earth is divided into these four, of these four is the year made up, in these four is the earth completed, and from these four is the Church collected.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:621
verses.text: For all who are considered to be joined to holy Church, by being called by the Divine Name, shall obtain the privilege of the resurrection and the grace of eternal bliss, for "they shall come from the east and west, and from the north and south, and shall sit down in the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:622
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:623
verses.text: For it is no small light wherewith Christ encompasses His world: since "His going forth is from the height of heaven, and His progress to the height thereof, nor is there any who can hide himself from His heat".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:624
verses.text: For with His Goodness He enlightens all, and wills not to reject but to amend the foolish, and desires not to exclude the hard-hearted from the Church, but to soften them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:625
verses.text: And so the Church in the Song of Songs and Christ in the Gospel invites them, saying: "Come unto Me, all ye who labour and are heavy laden, and I will refresh you; take My yoke upon you and learn of Me, for I am meek and lowly in heart".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:626
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:627
verses.text: And you may recognize also the voice of the invitation of the Church, for she says: "Awake, O north wind, and come, thou south, blow upon my garden, and let my ointment flow forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:628
verses.text: Let my brother come down into his garden and eat the fruit of his precious trees".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:629
verses.text: For knowing even then, O holy Church, that from those also there would be fruitful works for thee, thou didst promise to thy Christ fruit from such as they, thou who didst first say that thou wast brought into the King's chamber, loving His breast above wine, since thou lovedst Him Who loved thee, soughtest Him Who fed thee, and didst despise dangers for religion's sake.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:630
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:631
verses.text: And then, O Bride, thou art called to come from Libanus, being in the Lord's judgment all fair and without fault.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:632
verses.text: For thus it is written: "Thou art all fair, my love, and there is no fault in thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:633
verses.text: Come hither from Libanus, my bride, come hither from Libanus".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:634
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:635
verses.text: Afterwards, thou, fearing no rushing waters, no torrents coming down from Libanus, callest the north and south winds, wishing them to blow upon thy garden, that thy ointment may flow forth upon others, and that thou mayest offer to Christ in others the manifold fruits of thy productiveness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:636
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:637
verses.text: And therefore "blessed is he who keepeth the words of this prophecy," which has revealed the resurrection to us by clearer testimony, saying: "And I saw the dead, great and small, standing before the throne, and they opened the books; and another book was opened, which is the book of life; and the dead were judged out of the things which were written in the books, according to their works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:638
verses.text: And the sea gave up the dead which were in it, and hell gave up the dead which were in it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:639
verses.text: We must, then, not question how they shall rise again, whom hell gives up and the sea restores.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:640
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:641
verses.text: Hear also when the future grace of the just is promised: "And I heard," he says, "a great voice from the throne saying: Behold, the tabernacle of God is with men, and He shall dwell with them, and they  shall be His people, and God Himself shall be their God with them: and He shall wipe away every tear from their eyes; and death shall be no more, nor mourning, nor crying, nor pain, any more".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:642
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:643
verses.text: Compare now, if you will, and contrast this life with that; and choose, if you then can, unending bodily existence in toil, and in the wretched misery of such changes as we endure, in satiety when we have our wishes, in that disgust which attends our pleasures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:644
verses.text: If God were willing to let these last for ever, would you choose them? For if on its own account life is to be escaped from, that there may be an avoidance of troubles and rest from miseries, how much more is that rest to be sought for, which shall be followed by the eternal pleasure of the resurrection to come, where there is no succession of faults, no enticement to sin?  124.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:645
verses.text: Who is so patient in suffering as not to pray for death? who has such endurance in weakness as not to wish rather to die than to live in debility? Who is so brave in sorrow as not to desire to escape from it even by death? But if we ourselves are dissatisfied while life lasts, although we know that a limit is fixed for it, how much more weary should we become of this life if we saw that the troubles of the body would be with us without end! For who is there who would wish to be excepted from death? Or what would be more unendurable than a miserable immortality? "If in this life only," he says, "we hope in Christ, we are more miserable than all men;" not because to hope in Christ is miserable, but because Christ has prepared another life for those who hope in Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:646
verses.text: For this life is liable to sin, that life is reserved for the reward.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:647
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:648
verses.text: And how much weariness do we find that the short stages of our lives bring us! The boy longs to be a young man; the youth counts the years leading to riper age; the young man, unthankful for the advantage of his vigorous time of life, desires the honour of old age.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:649
verses.text: And so to all there comes naturally the desire of change, because we are dissatisfied with that which we now are.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:650
verses.text: And lastly, even the things we have desired are wearisome to us; and what we have wished to obtain, when we have obtained it, we dislike.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:651
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:652
verses.text: Wherefore holy men have not without reason often lamented their lengthy dwelling here: David lamented it, Jeremiah lamented it, and Elijah lamented it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:653
verses.text: If we believe wise men, and those in whom the Divine Spirit dwelt, they were hastening to better things; and if we enquire as to the judgment of others, that we may ascertain that all agree in one opinion, what great men have preferred death to sorrow, what great men have preferred it to fear! esteeming forsooth the fear of death to be worse than death itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:654
verses.text: So death is not feared on account of evils which belong to it, but is preferred to the miseries of life, since the departure of the dying is desired and the dread of the living is avoided.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:655
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:656
verses.text: So be it, then.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:657
verses.text: Granted that the Resurrection is preferable to this life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:658
verses.text: What! have philosophers themselves found anything with which we should have a greater delight to continue than to rise again? Even those indeed who say that souls are immortal do not satisfy me, seeing they only allow me a partial redemption.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:659
verses.text: What grace can that be by which I am not wholly benefited? What life is that if the operation of God dies out in me? What righteousness is that which, if death is the end of natural existence, is common to the sinner and the just? What is that truth, that the soul should be considered immortal, because it moves itself and is always in motion? As regards that which in the body is common to us with beasts, it is perhaps uncertain what happens before the body exists, and the truth is not to be gathered from these differences but destroyed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:660
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:661
verses.text: But is their opinion preferable, who say that our souls, when they have passed out of these bodies, migrate into the bodies of beasts, or of various other living creatures? Philosophers, indeed, themselves are wont to argue that these are ridiculous fancies of poets, such as might be produced by draughts of the drugs of Circe; and they say that not so much they who are represented to have undergone such things, as the senses of those who have invented such tales are changed into the forms of various beasts as it were by Circe's cup.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:662
verses.text: For what is so like a marvel as to believe that men could have been changed into the forms of beasts? How much greater a marvel, however, would it be that the soul which rules man should take on itself the nature of a beast so opposed to that of man, and being capable of reason should be able to pass over to an irrational animal, than that the form of the body should have been  changed? You yourselves, who teach these things, destroy what you teach.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:663
verses.text: For you have given up the production of these portentous conversions by means of magic incantations.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:664
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:665
verses.text: Poets say these things in sport, and philosophers blame them and at the same time they imagine that those very things are true of the dead which they consider fictitious as regards the living.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:666
verses.text: For they who invented such tales did not intend to assert the truth of their own fable, but to deride the errors of philosophers, who think that that same soul which was accustomed to overcome anger by gentle and lowly purpose, can now, inflamed by the raging impulses of a lion, impatient with anger and with unbridled rage, thirst for blood and seek for slaughter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:667
verses.text: Or again, that that soul, which as it were by royal counsel used to moderate the various storms of the people, and to calm them with the voice of reason, can now endure to howl in pathless and desert places after the fashion of a wolf; or that that soul which, groaning under a heavy burden, used to low in sad complaint over the labours of the plough, now changed into the fashion of a man, seeks for horns on his smooth brow; or that another, which used of old to be borne aloft on rapid wing to the heights of heaven, now thinks of flight no longer in its power, and mourns that it grows sluggish in the weight of a human body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:668
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:669
verses.text: Perchance you destroyed Icarus through some such teaching, because the youth, led on by your persuasion, imagined, it may be, that he had been a bird.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:670
verses.text: By such means too have many old men been deceived so as to submit to grievous pain, having unhappily believed the fables about swans, and thought that they, whilst soothing their pain with mournful strains, would be able to transmute their gray hair into downy feathers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:671
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:672
verses.text: How incredible are these things! how odious! How much more fitting is it to believe in accordance with nature, in accordance with what takes place in every kind of fruit; to believe in accordance with the pattern of what has happened, in accordance with the utterances of prophets, and the heavenly promise of Christ! For what is better than to be sure that the work of God does not perish, and that those who are made in the image and likeness of God cannot be transformed into the shapes of beasts; since in truth it is not the form of the body but of the spirit which is made after the likeness of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:673
verses.text: For in what manner could man, to whom are subjected the other kinds of living creatures, migrate with the better part of himself into an animal subjected to himself? Nature does not suffer this, and if nature did grace would not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:674
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:675
verses.text: But I have seen what you, Gentiles, think of each other, and indeed it ought not to seem strange that you who worship beasts should believe that you can be changed into beasts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:676
verses.text: But I had rather that you judged better concerning what is due to you, that you may believe that you will be not in the company of wild beasts, but in the companionship of angels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:677
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:678
verses.text: The soul has to depart from the surroundings of this life, and the pollutions of the earthly body, and to press on to those heavenly companies, though it is for the saints alone, to attain to them, and to sing praise to God (as in the prophet's words we hear of those who are harping and saying: "For great are Thy marvellous works, O Lord God Almighty, just and true are Thy ways, Thou King of the nations; who shall not fear and magnify Thy Name, for Thou only art holy, for all nations shall come and worship before Thee"), and to see Thy marriage feast, O Lord Jesus, in which the Bride is led from earthly to heavenly things, while all rejoice in harmony, for "to Thee shall all flesh come," now no longer subject to transitory things, but joined to the Spirit, to see the chambers adorned with linen, roses, lilies, and garlands.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:679
verses.text: Of whom else is the marriage so adorned? For it is adorned with the purple stripes of confessors, the blood of martyrs, the lilies of virgins, and the crowns of priests.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:680
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:681
verses.text: Holy David desired beyond all else for himself that he might behold and gaze upon this, for he says: "One thing have I asked of the Lord, that will I seek after; that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life, and see the pleasure of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:682
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:683
verses.text: It is a pleasure to believe this, a joy to hope for it; and certainly, not to have believed it is a pain, to have lived in this hope a grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:684
verses.text: But if I am mistaken in this, that I prefer to be associated after death with angels rather than with beasts, I am gladly mistaken, and so long as I live will never suffer myself to be cheated of this hope.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:685
Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:686
verses.text: For what comfort have I left but that I hope to come quickly to thee, my brother,  and that thy departure will not cause a long severance between us, and that it may be granted me, through thy intercessions, that thou mayest quickly call me who long for thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Decease of His Brother Styrus Book II 1:687
verses.text: For who is there who ought not to wish for himself beyond all else that "this corruptible should put on incorruption, and this mortal put on immortality"? that we who succumb to death through the frailty of the body, being raised above nature, may no longer have to fear death.
